Sheriff: New technology will help in emergencies 
Updated: Friday, October 16 2015, 06:29 PM EDT ALBANY COUNTY -- New technology is coming to Albany County that may help first responders get to you faster in case of an emergency. a new digital communications system is expected to launch about 6 months from now."It's a system that will allow every public safety system to talk together finally," said Albany County Sheriff Craig Apple.For years the county has been dealing with an issue that was exposed on a greater scale during the September 11th terror attacks in 2001. "You're calling in people for mutual aid who can’t talk to each other," Apple said.Old technology didn’t allow towns within the same to talk to each other on their radios. "Like Albany can't talk to Colonie and so forth," Apple said.It creates a huge problem when one city or town calls another in need of help responding to a big disaster. In the heat of the moment, the agencies showing up can't talk to the ones already on scene."As technology improves we need to invest in infrastructure," said State Senator George Amedore.Amedore helped secure a grant that will provide some of the digital radios departments will need to use the new system. The radios cost $3,000 each. After launching the system within Albany County, the sheriff says the county will link up with surrounding counties beginning with Saratoga County.
